text: at a tent Hospital near the
International Airport in port-au-prince
Haiti children severely injured in the
January 12th earthquake are in a fight
for their lives and the wounded keep
pouring in as you see they're just
bringing in patients more and more
patients these are three week old crush
injuries these are three week old
fractures that our orthopedic surgeons
are capable of doing surgery back home
but not in these conditions not with the
equipment we have here doctors here are
working in primitive conditions and
struggling with a severe shortage of
basic medical supplies and now they are
battling a different kind of foe
government bureaucracy here we are
trying to help these kids trying to get
these kids to America and there's just a
huge missed disconnect in America with
all the agencies and it's just you're
arctor see at its best
it changed specifically right after the
kidnap kidnappings we've we're really
our hands are tied now if you have no
papers in this country before you even
get to the airport in Puerto Plata in
port-au-prince you can't get to America
before the American kidnapping case this
field hospital was airlifting 15
severely injured children a day to the
United States aboard private flights
since the case broke last month only
three children have been flown out of
here on private planes
now children are stuck like this
five-year-old boy whose spine was
injured when a wall fell on him
this kid could possibly never move his
legs again if we don't get him repaired
and his injury was three weeks ago
and he's still here we can't fix his
broken vertebrae and the surgeons here
are afraid that the vertebra may heal
incorrectly which could permanently lead
him to either a quadriplegic or a
paraplegic dr. Byas says the problem is
simple it's strictly paperwork we don't
have the paperwork we can't get him to
America where there's many hospitals
that would help them for free physicians
here say that American and Haitian
officials are now asking for documents
proving that the children they want to
send to the u.s. are orphans or that the
adult traveling with them is a parent a
challenging task in a country ravaged by
the earthquake nobody here has papers
there's no driver's licenses that the
dads or the moms can identify themselves
as who they are the children have no
birth certificates last night I made
three birth certificates for the three
babies that were born here on a
letterhead on a on an Apple computer no
pilot in their right mind is gonna take
off from the US without a paper in ten
that says when you get to Haiti you will
be permitted to pick up this patient and
when you get back here no one's gonna
give you grief about it
um and the kidnapping hasn't helped
anything nor has the reporting of the
kidnapping helped anything
previously children with
life-threatening conditions were
airlifted out of the country immediately
after triage the paperwork was completed
after the children were stabilized but
the pilots say they now risk big fines
or worse for transporting undocumented
Haitians to the US I think there is a
fear that the pilots don't want to
jeopardize their operation to bring
people in and out for that one chance
that might cause them the headache
u.s. military evacuations have finally
resumed after a five-day halt late last
month but doctors here say approvals are
too slow and requirements too severe on
who can go most medical air lifts to the
US have flown on smaller private flights
for now those flights are few and far
between meanwhile lives are held in the
balance this little girl here had a
really bad accident during the
earthquake four of her family members
were trapped under the house three three
of them died on the scene the family
members on the scene amputated her left
foot to try to get her out cuz she was
crushed underneath the house because of
infection spreading doctors here had to
amputate her her other foot last night
you know we're trying the best we can we
don't have enough antibiotics we don't
have enough wound care to take care of
her and and we're trying to get her to
America but we can't and she's lost her
other foot because of that the
hospital's chief administrative officer
Elizabeth Gregg says that they are
trying to untangle the red tape
meanwhile says dr. vias lives are being
lost since I've been here I have had
five kids died all five of those kids I
desperately tried desperately tried to
get them to America and excuse me it
just is it sucks you know like these
kids could they died and
with the care they could have gotten any
Hospital in America they would have
survived and I have to I'm the one ended
up dealing telling their parents that we
tried everything and in my heart we
didn't do we couldn't do everything in
my heart these kids could have survived
and they could have lived normal lives
this is Eric Olsen reporting for The New
York Times from port-au-prince Haiti
